results.body:
PESHAWAR, Pakistan -- A police official says a roadside bomb has wounded six tribal policemen escorting a team of polio workers in northwest Pakistan.
 Police official Nawabzada Khan says the attack took place Saturday when an anti-polio team was traveling through the Lashora village of Jamrud tribal region in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province.
 He says all the polio workers were unharmed, as the bomb hit only the escort vehicle.
 No one claimed responsibility, but anti-polio teams or their guards have been frequently targeted in Pakistan by Islamic militants, who say the campaigns are a tool for spying and claim the vaccine makes boys sterile.
 Pakistan is one of the few remaining countries where polio persists and most cases found in its northwest, where militants make it difficult to reach children for vaccination.
results.title: Roadside bomb wounds 6 tribal policemen escorting polio team in northwest Pakistan

6 cops escorting polio team wounded in Jamrud blast
MONITORING DESK PESHAWAR: A police official says a roadside bomb has wounded six tribal policemen escorting a team of polio workers in northwest Pakistan.
 Police official Nawabzada Khan says the attack took place Saturday when an anti-polio team was traveling through the Lashora village of Jamrud tribal region in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province.
 He says all the polio workers were unharmed, as the bomb hit only the escort vehicle.  No one claimed responsibility, but anti-polio teams or their guards have been frequently targeted in Pakistan by militants, who say the campaigns are a tool for spying and claim the vaccine makes boys sterile.
 Pakistan is one of the few remaining countries where polio persists and most cases found in its northwest, where militants make it difficult to reach children for vaccination.  (Local TV)
results.title: 6 cops escorting polio team wounded in Jamrud blast

results.body:
PESHAWAR: A double bombing struck convoys of tribal police assigned to guard polio workers in a northwest Pakistan on Saturday, killing six of them, police said.
 Police official Nawabzada Khan said six officers were wounded when the first bomb hit a police escort vehicle in the Lashora village of Jamrud tribal region in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province.
 Khan said minutes later, another roadside bomb struck a convoy of tribal police officers dispatched there to transport victims of the first attack, killing six officers and wounding 14 others.  He said gunmen also opened fire, triggering a shootout that was still going on.
 "Initial reports suggest that at least six tribal police officers have been killed and 20 have been wounded in the two separate bomb attacks, but all the polio workers are safe," he said.
 No one claimed responsibility for the two separate bombings, but anti-polio teams or their guards have been frequently targeted in Pakistan by Islamic militants, who say the campaigns are a tool for spying and claim the vaccine makes boys sterile.
 Pakistan is one of the few remaining countries where polio persists and most cases found in its northwest, where militants make it difficult to reach children for vaccination.
results.title: Bombs kill 6 Pakistani police guarding polio teams

results.body:
A double bombing struck convoys of tribal police assigned to guard polio workers in a northwest Pakistan on Saturday, killing at least six of them, police said.  Some reports said 10 died.
 Police official Nawabzada Khan said six officers were wounded when the first bomb hit a police escort vehicle in the Lashora village of Jamrud tribal region in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province.
 Khan said minutes later, another roadside bomb struck a convoy of tribal police officers dispatched there to transport victims of the first attack, killing six officers and wounding 14 others.  He said gunmen also opened fire, triggering a shootout that was still going on.
 "Initial reports suggest that at least six tribal police officers have been killed and 20 have been wounded in the two separate bomb attacks, but all the polio workers are safe," he said.
 No one claimed responsibility for the two separate bombings, but anti-polio teams or their guards have been frequently targeted in Pakistan by Islamic militants, who say the campaigns are a tool for spying and claim the vaccine makes boys sterile.
 Pakistan is one of the few remaining countries where polio persists and most cases found in its northwest, where militants make it difficult to reach children for vaccination.
results.title: Bombs kill Pakistani police officers guarding polio teams

results.body:
AP A file picture shows a Pakistani child displaced from Pak tribal areas being administered polio drop.
 Two bombs went off Saturday in Pakistan's north-western tribal region, killing 10 and injuring 11 policemen who were guarding polio vaccinators, officials said.
 The men from the tribal Khasardar Force were escorting a team of polio vaccinators in the area of Jamrud in Khyber district when two vehicles were targeted with separate bombs planted by the road, an official from the tribal administration said.
 He said the polio workers survived the attacks and that the two vehicles were destroyed.
 Private Geo TV reported that a child was also killed.
 No group has yet claimed responsibility for the bombings, but Islamist militants have targeted vaccination teams in the past.
 In the last year alone, officials say that about two dozen health workers and security officials deployed to protect them have been killed by rebels.
 Polio has reappeared in parts of north-western Pakistan under the control of Islamist militants linked to al-Qaeda, according to the World Health Organization (WHO).
 Insurgents accuse health workers of acting as spies for the United States, and claim the polio vaccine is intended to make Muslim children sterile.
 Following widespread vaccination campaigns since the 1950s, polio is only endemic in Pakistan, Afghanistan and Nigeria.
 WHO says Pakistan is the only country in the world where the number of new polio cases was on the rise in 2013.
results.title: 10 policemen guarding Pak polio vaccinators killed in bombings - The Hindu

results.body:
Around a dozen other police officers were injured in the attack, in which two vehicles are reported to have been hit by bombs planted along the side of the road they were travelling along in the Jamrud tribal region in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province.
 The Associated Press cited a local official who said that no-one was killed but several police officers were wounded when the first bomb struck a vehicle escorting the vaccination team.
 The fatalities came a few minutes later, when the second bomb hit a convoy of tribal police officers which had been sent to pick up the victims of the first attack.  The official said that 11 were killed in the bombing, and gunmen had opened fire on the policemen who emerged unhurt.
 A separate official said a manhunt had been launched in an effort to find and arrest the attackers.
 Frequent targets
There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the attack, but polio-vaccination teams have frequently been targeted by Islamist militants in Pakistan, who claim that such campaigns are a cover for spying activities, while at the same time making boys sterile.
 Pakistan is one of the few country where polio remains prevalent, and according to the World Health Organization, in 2013 it was the only country in the world in which the disease was on the rise.  Most polio cases are recorded in Pakistan's northwestern tribal region, which is difficult for vaccinating teams to reach.
 The country's neighbor and chief rival, India, meanwhile, recently celebrated being declared free of the disease, after three years without a new diagnosed case.
results.title: At least 11 Pakistani police officers killed in attack on polio vaccination team

results.body:
ISLAMABAD -- Two bombs went off Saturday in Pakistan's restive northwestern tribal region, killing 10 and injuring 11 policemen who were guarding polio vaccinators, officials said.
 The men from the tribal Khasardar Force were escorting a team of polio vaccinators in the area of Jamrud in Khyber district when two vehicles were targeted with separate bombs planted by the road, an official from the tribal administration told dpa.
 He said the polio workers survived the attacks and that the two vehicles were destroyed.
 Private Geo TV reported that a child was also killed.
 No group has yet claimed responsibility for the bombings, but Islamist militants have targeted vaccination teams in the past.
 In the last year alone, officials say that about two dozen health workers and security officials deployed to protect them have been killed by rebels.
 Polio has reappeared in parts of northwestern Pakistan under the control of Islamist militants linked to al-Qaida, according to the World Health Organization (WHO).
 Insurgents accuse health workers of acting as spies for the United States, and claim the polio vaccine is intended to make Muslim children sterile.
 Following widespread vaccination campaigns since the 1950s, polio is only endemic in Pakistan, Afghanistan and Nigeria.
 WHO says Pakistan is the only country in the world where the number of new polio cases was on the rise in 2013.
results.title: 10 police guarding Pakistani polio vaccinators killed in bombings

results.body:
The militant group's announcement came hours after two roadside bombs killed 11 security officers and a civilian and injured five others in the Khyber Agency tribal area.  The attack was aimed at a polio vaccination team, a frequent target of the Pakistani Taliban and its allies.
 Spokesman Shahid Ullah Shahid told reporters that the group, known by its Urdu name Tehreek-e-Taliban Pakistan, or TTP, would observe an unconditional cease-fire in the interests of the nation.  "Outfits affiliated with the TTP should also abide by the decision," he said.
 The TTP was under growing pressure to declare a cease-fire after the Pakistan Air Force carried out several days of strikes on suspected hideouts of the group in the tribal area of North Waziristan.  The Pakistani government stepped up its bombing campaign after suspending peace talks amid ongoing violence attributed to the insurgents, particularly in the provincial capital of Peshawar.
 Pakistani officials claimed that the airstrikes killed more than 100 suspected militants, although the numbers could not be confirmed independently.
 Interior Minister Chaudhry Nisar Ali Khan told reporters in the provincial capital of Peshawar last week that the insurgents must declare a unilateral cease-fire before talks could resume between government negotiators and representatives appointed by the Pakistani Taliban.
 The head of the government negotiating committee, Irfan Siddiqi, told Pakistan's Geo Television that the insurgent group's announcement was "a big breakthrough," the Associated Pres reported.
 Hours before the announcement, however, the twin bombings against the polio vaccination team in the Jamrud tribal area outside Peshawar illustrated how difficult it may be for the insurgent organization to rein in allied militants.
 Local official Ali Sher said that one roadside bomb hit a vehicle carrying guards who were on their way to provide security to health workers, wounding five of the guards.  After the blast, authorities dispatched a vehicle to retrieve the injured when a second bomb planted along the road exploded, killing 11 guards and one passerby, a student, Sher said.
 A three-day polio vaccination campaign in the tribal area began on Thursday, with officials saying that approximately 130,000 children under the age of 5 were to be immunized.
 No group immediately claimed responsibility for the bombings, but Islamist militants have routinely attacked anti-polio teams because they believe vaccination campaigns are a cover for Western espionage.  The government has dispatched guards to provide security to health workers.
 Pakistan is one of just three countries where polio remains prevalent, particularly in Peshawar, the capital of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province, according to the U.N. World Health Organization.  So far this year, 22 new polio cases -- 19 from the tribal areas and three from Khyber Pakhtunkhwa -- have been reported in Pakistan.
 Afghanistan security at risk in U.S. pullout, official says
Yanukovich says he's still Ukraine leader, calls on Russia to 'act'
results.title: Pakistani Taliban calls one-month cease-fire

results.body:
JAMRUD: Eleven khasadar officials who were providing security to a polio team were injured in two separate blasts in Jamrud, Express News reported on Saturday.
 In the first incident, five officials sustained injuries in an explosion near a polio team's vehicle in the Lashoro area of the town.
 In the second blast, six other officials were injured.  The vehicle of the line officer of the polio team was reportedly the target of the second attack.
 The injured were taken to Hayatabad Medical Complex for medical assistance.  Six of the officials succumbed to their injuries.
 Polio teams have been the target of various attacks in the country.  Militant groups see vaccination campaigns as a cover for espionage there are also long-running rumours about polio drops causing infertility.
 Pakistan is one of only three countries in the world where polio is still endemic, along with Afghanistan and Nigeria.
 According to the World Health Organisation, Pakistan recorded 91 cases of polio last year, up from 58 in 2012.
results.title: Polio team targeted: 2 khasadar officials killed, 9 others injured in Jamrud blasts

results.body:
Bilawal Bhutto Zardari paid glowing tribute to slain Pakistan People's Party (PPP) leader Shahbaz Bhatti on his 3rd death anniversary on Sunday.
 Bhatti, then federal minister for minority affairs, was killed by terrorists on March 2, 2011, near his home in Islamabad.
 Bilwal, who is patron-in-chief of the PPP, said in a statement that the party had a history of giving sacrifices for the protection and rights of the people of Pakistan without any caste, creed, sect or religious discrimination.
 "Shaheed Shahbaz Bhatti also laid down his life for a cause and he will always be remembered as a great son of Pakistan who fought for the nation's unity and integrity so valiantly." "
Bilawal said the "PPP stands for the right of the people of minority communities", and assured them of his party's full support and protection against any injustice.
 In a separate statement, the young PPP leader condemned an attack on polio workers in Jamrud, which resulted in the loss of precious human lives.
 He said health workers and volunteers served humanity by participating in an anti-polio drive and should be provided security by the government.
 "All involved in the polio campaign are selfless volunteers.  They do this to save lives and they do this to save the future of Pakistan." "
Bilawal called upon the government to do its utmost to protect health workers and create a secure environment so that the health needs of the children of nation could be met.
 He prayed to Almighty Allah to grant eternal peace to the departed souls and courage to the bereaved families to bear this irreparable loss with equanimity.
results.title: Bilawal pays tribute to slain PPP leader Shahbaz Bhatti

results.body:
The UAE yesterday condemned in the strongest possible terms the terrorist bomb blasts on Saturday in Pakistan's north-western tribal region, killing 12 and injuring 12 policemen who were guarding polio vaccinators.
 'The terrorist blast reveals the cruelty of its perpetrators, H.H. Sheikh Abdullah bin Zayed Al Nahyan, Foreign Minister, affirmed in a statement to state news agency (WAM), expressing the UAE's solidarity with the government of Pakistan in its efforts to combating the black terrorism.
 Sheikh Abdullah called on countries of the world to stand together in the fight against terrorism in all its forms and manifestations.
 He also expressed his heart-felt condolences to Pakistani government and the bereaved families of the victims.  He also wished speedy recovery to those injured in the attack.  - Emirates News Agency, WAM
results.title: UAE strongly condemns terror attacks on polio vaccinators in Pakistan

results.body:
The highly advanced and multidimensional anti-IED operations have kick-started thus leading to radical improvements in overall security system across Pakistan as the two armed forces' units on this assignment have attained a near-perfection status in these operations.
 Talking to The News on condition of anonymity, a responsible defence official said the anti-IED division established within the armed forces, that is known as IEDEF had become fully functional in multidimensional anti-IED operations in various cities and troubled areas of the country side by side with comprehensive awareness campaigns that were also in the process of being launched now.
 According to the official, extra security measures have been taken at all levels and on all tiers in order to curb the incidents of Improvised Explosive Device (IED) attacks in the market places, civilian gatherings and religious processions.
 According to the last one month's (January) data acquired from the formations as well as intelligence agencies, the official said, a total of 270 incidents of IED attacks occurred, which took lives of 145 military personnel and wounded 469; out of 270, 207 attacks were made in the troubled areas of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa and 55 in the Balochistan province's southern command area.
 The official told this scribe that the terrorists were resorting to more intensive and lethal attacks as compared to the previous months.
 "A 70 percent increase in the IED attacks was observed during the month of January 2014 as compared to December 2013.  It meant an overall 106 percent increase as compared to 2013, since the start of this year." "
The official also disclosed that the terrorists were using modern techniques, lethal chemicals, material and sophisticated time devices such as RCIED and VBIED which hit the target at point blank, and were difficult to prevent.  Explaining these terms, the official said RCIED stands for Armoured Carrier Borne IED while VBIED is a Vehicle Borne IED.
 "They select sensitive areas, public places, gatherings, markets and mosques as their main target and government offices, installations, schools, gas pipelines, FC and police patrols or convoys, roadsides and railway tracks as their secondary targets", said the official.
 Explaining the background of this force, the official said it was during the incumbency of former Army Chief General Ashfaq Parvez Kayani, that two anti-IEDEF units were formally inducted, which started functioning from September 20, 2013 under the umbrella of its central office known as CIEDO headquarters.  These units have now undergone marked improvement and expansion and they are already actively playing their role in educating the uniformed personnel besides working on comprehensive awareness programmes for the general public.  At the same time, they are recommending preventive measures and awareness campaigns through media as well as at the governments' levels.
 The IEDEF has also issued an SOP (Standard Operating Procedure) to be circulated to all units and command formations with instructions, preventive and remedial measures and steps as how to tackle and defuse or exploit the explosive and prevent the lives from IEDs.
 Police cops and FC personnel, especially those on patrolling duty, have been asked to observe extra vigilance and follow the instructions as in the SOP.
 The SOP suggests measures for VIP route safety, saying the road opening day (ROD) should be on staggered days instead of Sundays and the movement should be kept secret till the very last moment to avoid well-planned IED incidents.
 Media is also being requested to play its role in educating the general public about IED threats as well as the responsibility as how to inform the security personnel as and when anything suspicious is observed.
 Evidences, the SOP says, must be collected from the place of incident in their original form and transferred for exploitation on fast track basis.  "This would help identify the enemy and enter into the proactive phase of response", said the official.
results.title: Anti-IED force fully operational

results.body:
DEEP MILAN PRADHAN, MIRIK, 1 Mar 2014: CB Sinchury, former vice-president of the Akhil Bharatiya Scheduled Caste and Tribe and Minority Federation state committee, has welcomed the proposal of the state government to list the backward communities of the Gorkhas under the Scheduled Tribe category.
 Terming it a right move on the state government's part, he said communities such as the Rai, Limbu, Dewan, Gurung, Bhujel, Newar, Mukhia, Mangar, Tamang and Thami will appreciate the gesture although they "should have been listed as tribes a long time back".
 Sinchury added the Gorkha commuinities have been deprived of several facilities as most are listed under the general category.  He noted said the Gorkhas embraced Hinduism and its culture much later causing a decline in tribal practices.
 "Once the Gorkhas are listed as tribal people, their traditions will get revived," he remarked.
results.title: Tribal traditions will revive post ST status: Sinchury

results.body:
Unos miembros de las fuerzas de seguridad afganas inspeccionan el lugar donde se ...
 Kabul, 2 mar (EFE).- - Trece personas -nueve talibanes, y dos niños y dos mujeres- murieron hoy cuando estallaron accidentalmente los explosivos que llevaban los insurgentes en un camión bomba en la provincia de Logar, en el este de Afganistán, informó una fuente oficial.
 La detonación ocurrió al mediodía local en el área de Baboos en la ciudad de Pul-e-Alam, capital provincial, a donde los insurgentes llevaban el camión para cometer un atentado, dijo a Efe el portavoz del Gobierno de la provincia, Din Mohamed Darwish.
 De acuerdo con la fuente, los explosivos que eran transportados en el vehículo detonaron antes de llegar a su objetivo.
 "Nueve insurgentes, entre ellos seis paquistaníes, murieron", precisó Darwish, quien añadió que también perdieron la vida dos mujeres y dos niños que se encontraban en el interior de sus casas, que fueron destruidas por la onda expansiva.
 El pasado miércoles diez civiles murieron y 40 resultaron heridos cuando un terrorista suicida detonó accidentalmente explosivos en el hotel en el que se alojaba en la ciudad de Trinkot, en la provincia de Uruzgán, en el sur de Afganistán.
 Según un comunicado del Gobierno central, el insurgente planeaba perpetrar un atentado al día siguiente.
 El conflicto afgano se halla en uno de sus momentos más sangrientos desde la invasión de EEUU que propició la caída del régimen talibán hace doce años y a dos meses de la celebración de elecciones generales.
 El presente año es el último con presencia de tropas de la OTAN en Afganistán, de acuerdo con un calendario de retirada gradual que concluirá en diciembre próximo, cuando las fuerzas locales asumirán la seguridad en todo el territorio del país.
results.title: Thirteen dead to exploit accidentally a truck bomb in afghanistan

results.body:

results.title: Trece muertos al explotar accidentalmente un camión bomba en Afganistán

results.body:
13 muertos en Afganistán por la explosión accidental de un coche bomba 02 Mar 2014 Puli Alam (Afganistán) (AFP)
Al menos trece personas murieron este domingo en la provincia de Logar, al sur de Kabul, a consecuencia de la explosión accidental de un coche bomba, que un grupo de insurgentes talibanes estaba preparando, indicaron unos responsables locales.
 "Fallecieron nueve talibanes, algunos de ellos paquistaníes, dos mujeres y dos niños", declaró a la AFP el jefe adjunto de la policía local, Abdul Wali Toofan.
 "Querían llenar el coche de explosivos para cometer un atentado en un barrio concurrido" de Puli Alam, capital de Logar, "pero el vehículo explotó en la casa", precisó.
 El gobierno provincial explicó que el coche bomba podría haberse utilizado para perturbar la campaña electoral de las presidenciales del mes de abril.  No hubo supervivientes, añadió.
results.title: 13 dead in afghanistan by the explosión adventitious a car bomb

 El conflicto afgano se halla en uno de sus momentos más sangrientos desde la invasión de EEUU que propició la caída del régimen talibán hace doce años y a dos meses de la celebración de elecciones generales.
 El presente año es el último con presencia de tropas de la OTAN en Afganistán, de acuerdo con un calendario de retirada gradual que concluirá en diciembre próximo, cuando las fuerzas locales asumirán la seguridad en todo el territorio del país.
results.title: Thirteen dead to exploit accidentally a truck bomb in afghanistan

results.body:
Diez civiles murieron y 40 resultaron heridos cuando un terrorista suicida detonó accidentalmente explosivos en el hotel en el que se alojaba en el sur de Afganistán, informó hoy el Ministerio afgano del Interior.
 La explosión sucedió este martes por la tarde en la ciudad de Trinkot, en la provincia de Uruzgán y el terrorista planeaba llevar a cabo un atentado hoy, de acuerdo con un comunicado de Interior.
 Los heridos fueron trasladados a un hospital por las fuerzas de seguridad.
 Los atentados suicidas son junto a los artefactos explosivos improvisados los métodos más utilizados por los talibanes contra las fuerzas afganas e internacionales, aunque en la práctica causan un elevado número de víctimas civiles.
 El conflicto afgano se halla en uno de sus momentos más sangrientos desde la invasión de EEUU que propició la caída del régimen talibán hace doce años y a dos meses de la celebración de elecciones generales.
 El presente año es el último con presencia de tropas de la OTAN en Afganistán, de acuerdo con un calendario de retirada gradual que concluirá en diciembre próximo, cuando las fuerzas locales asumirán la seguridad en todo el territorio del país.
 Fuente de imagen: EFE
results.title: 10 killed by accidental explosion suicide load in afghanistan

results.body:
Kabul, Afganistan -- Un coche cargado con explosivos estalló ayer domingo con resultado de 13 muertos, entre estos nueve insurgentes, en el este de Afganistán, dijeron las autoridades.
 Todo parece indicar que se trató de extremistas que murieron a causa de su propia arma, dijo el portavoz de la provincia de Logar, Dind Mohammad Darwesh.
 Al parecer el vehículo era preparado para la comisión de un atentado terrorista y prosiguen las investigaciones, agregó.
results.title: ... y carro bomba mata a 13 - Diario Digital Juárez

results.body:
KABUL, Afganistán -- Un coche cargado con explosivos estalló el domingo con resultado de 13 muertos, entre estos nueve insurgentes, en el este de Afganistán, dijeron las autoridades.
 Todo parece indicar que se trató de extremistas que murieron a causa de su propia arma, dijo el portavoz de la provincia de Logar, Dind Mohammad Darwesh.
 Al parecer el vehículo era preparado para la comisión de un atentado terrorista y prosiguen las investigaciones, agregó.
 Dijo que los fallecidos por la explosión fueron nueve insurgentes, además de dos mujeres y dos niños que se encontraban en las cercanías, apuntó.
 Darwesh aseguró que carecía de mayores detalles sobre lo sucedido.
results.title: Estallido deja 13 muertos en el este de Afganistán

results.body:
Unos miembros de las fuerzas de seguridad afganas inspeccionan el lugar donde se registró un atentado con bomba en Lashkargah, en la provincia de Helmand, Afganistán, el pasado lunes.  EFE
Cinco talibanes, entre ellos un importante comandante, murieron en el bombardeo lanzado por un avión no tripulado de Estados Unidos en la provincia de Kunar, en el este de Afganistán, informó hoy una fuente oficial.
 El avión no tripulado o 'drone' llevó a cabo el ataque ayer en el área de Darin, en el distrito de Ghaziabad, dijo a la agencia local PTI el jefe de la Policía provincial, Abdul Habib Saidkhil.
 Entre los fallecidos se encuentra el comandante taliban Abdul Rahim, también conocido como Khubaib, de acuerdo con la fuente.
 Los bombardeos con "drones" son muy controvertidos en Afganistán, especialmente por la muerte de civiles.
 Estados Unidos y Afganistán negocian un pacto militar para el mantenimiento de tropas estadounidenses en suelo afgano cuando las fuerzas de la OTAN se retiren en 2014.
 A pesar de que la Loya Jirga -asamblea tradicional- dio el visto bueno al acuerdo el pasado noviembre, Karzai quiere posponer la firma del mismo hasta la celebración de las elecciones generales el próximo año.
 Sin embargo, Estados Unidos quiere rubricar el acuerdo cuando antes.
 El borrador del pacto prevé la presencia en el país de entre 10.000 y 15.000 soldados estadounidenses desde 2015 hasta 2024.
results.title: 5 talibanes muertos en un ataque con un avión no tripulado en Afganistán

results.body:
Imagen de los restos de un vehículo utilizado en un atentado suicida contra un convoy de la OTAN, en Kabul, Afganistán.  EFE/Archivo
Dos soldados de la misión de la OTAN en Afganistán (ISAF) murieron en un ataque cometido por dos desconocidos que vestían el uniforme de las fuerzas de seguridad afganas, informó hoy a Efe la Alianza Atlántica.
 "Podemos confirmar que dos soldados de la ISAF murieron ayer cuando dos hombres que vestían el uniforme de las fuerzas de seguridad afganas les dispararon", dijo la portavoz de la organización multilateral Annmarie Annicelli.
 La ISAF afirmó que el ataque ocurrió en un punto no precisado del este del país asiático y no desveló la nacionalidad de las víctimas, algo que corresponde a cada Estado miembro de la organización.
 El gobernador de la provincia de Kapisa, Mehrabudin Safi, afirmó que el ataque ocurrió en el distrito de Tagab de su región, de acuerdo con la televisión local Tolo.
 El portavoz talibán Zabiulá Muyahid dijo al mismo medio que los dos soldados afganos eran miembros de la insurgencia.
 En los últimos años han aumentado los ataques de soldados o policías afganos contra las fuerzas internacionales destacadas en el país con las que patrullan conjuntamente, realizan operaciones o colaboran en determinadas tareas.
 Estas acciones son conocidas en jerga militar como ataques "green on blue" (verde contra azul), en alusión al color de los uniformes de las respectivas fuerzas.
 En 2012, se registraron más de medio centenar de ataques, aunque la tendencia disminuyó en 2013, al calor del papel cada vez más secundario que desempeñan las tropas extranjeras en Afganistán, país del que tienen previsto retirarse completamente en 2014.
 A menudo, los rebeldes talibanes asumen las acciones y aseguran haber infiltrado a sus combatientes en las filas de las fuerzas de seguridad afganas, como ha sucedido en este caso.
 El conflicto en el país centroasiático se encuentra en uno de los momentos más sangrientos desde la invasión estadounidense que propició la caída del régimen integrista talibán a finales de 2001 y celebra elecciones generales en abril.
results.title: Mueren dos soldados de la OTAN en un ataque de uniformados afganos

results.body:
Diez civiles murieron en la tarde del martes y otros 40 resultaron heridos cuando un terrorista suicida detonó accidentalmente explosivos en el hotel en el que se alojaba en el sur de Afganistán, según ha informado este miércoles el Ministerio del Interior afgano.
 La explosión ocurrió en la ciudad de Trinkot, en la provincia de Uruzgán.  Los heridos fueron trasladados a un hospital por las fuerzas de seguridad.
 Según el Ministerio del Interior, el terrorista planeaba llevar a cabo un atentado este miércoles.
 Los atentados suicidas son, junto a los artefactos explosivos improvisados, los métodos más utilizados por los talibanes contra las fuerzas afganas y las tropas internacionales, pero en la práctica causan un elevado número de víctimas civiles.
results.title: Diez muertos en Afganistán por la explosión accidental de un suicida
